flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
I saw a few NES tables around the internet and fell in love with the idea. However, they all fell in either the "not quite what I'm after" or "there's no flippin' way I'm paying that!" category.

Although it would have been awesome to have a giant working controller, I thought the novelty would wear off pretty quick. Instead I wanted something that was a bit more subtle, looked good, and showed off some nice wood.

Here's how I made mine....
guide.introduction_rendered:
I saw a few NES tables around the internet and fell in love with the idea. However, they all fell in either the "not quite what I'm after" or "there's no flippin' way I'm paying that!" category.

Although it would have been awesome to have a giant working controller, I thought the novelty would wear off pretty quick. Instead I wanted something that was a bit more subtle, looked good, and showed off some nice wood.

Here's how I made mine....

lines.text: First I got my trusty controller out and hit it with some digital calipers to get all the dimensions.
lines.text_raw: First I got my trusty controller out and hit it with some digital calipers to get all the dimensions.

lines.text: Armed with the dimensions I drew up the face on AutoCAD, scaled it up to the size I wanted (about 1m long), and worked out some details for some basic designs.
lines.text_raw: Armed with the dimensions I drew up the face on AutoCAD, scaled it up to the size I wanted (about 1m long), and worked out some details for some basic designs.

lines.text: I didn't stick too rigidly to the plan...I'm a bit of a geek, though, so it was important to me to get the top spot-on.
lines.text_raw: I didn't stick too rigidly to the plan...I'm a bit of a geek, though, so it was important to me to get the top spot-on.

lines.text: There's 3 colours on an NES controller...  Black→Oak; Grey→Maple; Red→Mahogany.  I was thinking of using walnut for the black bits...but I really like oak!
lines.text_raw: There's 3 colours on an NES controller...  Black→Oak; Grey→Maple; Red→Mahogany.  I was thinking of using walnut for the black bits...but I really like oak!

lines.text: First up I went to my local timber yard and selected some nice bits of oak, and got a few maple & mahogany offcuts too.
lines.text_raw: First up I went to my local timber yard and selected some nice bits of oak, and got a few maple & mahogany offcuts too.

lines.text: I cut the oak roughly to size, and fed it to my planer/thicknesser until I had some nice square bits of wood.
lines.text_raw: I cut the oak roughly to size, and fed it to my planer/thicknesser until I had some nice square bits of wood.

lines.text: Then I glued it together using "Resintite" wood glue (kinda like Urea-formaldehyde adhesive) and plenty of clamps.
lines.text_raw: Then I glued it together using "Resintite" wood glue (kinda like Urea-formaldehyde adhesive) and plenty of clamps.

lines.text: When dry the glue got scraped off and I had a good go at it with a belt sander.  Not pictured here...but I got some glass cut at this stage for the top (as I didn't trust them to cut it accurately enough later). Then I cut the oak panel to match the glass.
lines.text_raw: When dry the glue got scraped off and I had a good go at it with a belt sander.  Not pictured here...but I got some glass cut at this stage for the top (as I didn't trust them to cut it accurately enough later). Then I cut the oak panel to match the glass.

lines.text: I marked out where all the details on the top were to go, and found the center points of the radiuses of the corners.
lines.text_raw: I marked out where all the details on the top were to go, and found the center points of the radiuses of the corners.

lines.text: I drilled little pilot holes and drilled all the corners with a Forstner bit, then scored in lines between the edges of each corner with a sharp knife.
lines.text_raw: I drilled little pilot holes and drilled all the corners with a Forstner bit, then scored in lines between the edges of each corner with a sharp knife.

lines.text: I then took out the bulk using my router at a depth of 4mm. All the rest was taken out with chisel & mallet.
lines.text_raw: I then took out the bulk using my router at a depth of 4mm. All the rest was taken out with chisel & mallet.

lines.text: A long day of chiseling later, and all the rebates were done!
lines.text_raw: A long day of chiseling later, and all the rebates were done!

lines.text: I took my maple and mahogany and ripped it as thin as I dared, then thicknessed it as thin as I could (just over 5mm).
lines.text_raw: I took my maple and mahogany and ripped it as thin as I dared, then thicknessed it as thin as I could (just over 5mm).

lines.text: With a lot of patience I shaped all the maple so it slotted perfectly into the rebates.
lines.text_raw: With a lot of patience I shaped all the maple so it slotted perfectly into the rebates.

lines.text: Then it got glued & clamped in place, and sanded flush with a belt sander.
lines.text_raw: Then it got glued & clamped in place, and sanded flush with a belt sander.

lines.text: For the D-pad, I first thicknessed a bit of oak and made it into a little panel. It then got shaped to fit into the rebate.
lines.text_raw: For the D-pad, I first thicknessed a bit of oak and made it into a little panel. It then got shaped to fit into the rebate.

lines.text: It needed a 6mm maple edging, though. So I made a template off it using a flush bit in my router, then I rebated off the template with a 6mm rebating bit.
lines.text_raw: It needed a 6mm maple edging, though. So I made a template off it using a flush bit in my router, then I rebated off the template with a 6mm rebating bit.

lines.text: I thicknessed some maple to 6mm and worked it to surround the cross.
lines.text_raw: I thicknessed some maple to 6mm and worked it to surround the cross.

lines.text: Then glued....clamped....sanded flush.
lines.text_raw: Then glued....clamped....sanded flush.

lines.text: Annoyingly, the oak I used for the cross looked completely different from the rest of the tabletop. I recommend just making a 6mm channel and filling it with maple instead.
lines.text_raw: Annoyingly, the oak I used for the cross looked completely different from the rest of the tabletop. I recommend just making a 6mm channel and filling it with maple instead.

lines.text: Right....now for the dreaded letter detailing!
lines.text_raw: Right....now for the dreaded letter detailing!

lines.text: I found an NES font & Nintendo logo and added them to my CAD drawing.
lines.text_raw: I found an NES font & Nintendo logo and added them to my CAD drawing.

lines.text: I put masking tape over everywhere there were to be words on the tabletop, and projected my drawing on to it.
lines.text_raw: I put masking tape over everywhere there were to be words on the tabletop, and projected my drawing on to it.

lines.text: Then I traced around the projected words with a pen and cut through the tape to score the letters into the oak.
lines.text_raw: Then I traced around the projected words with a pen and cut through the tape to score the letters into the oak.

lines.text: This also provided me with a perfect template for the mahogany inlay.
lines.text_raw: This also provided me with a perfect template for the mahogany inlay.

lines.text: I chiseled the letters out by hand so they had about a 3mm rebate.
lines.text_raw: I chiseled the letters out by hand so they had about a 3mm rebate.

lines.text: I then shaped the mahogany by hand to fit perfectly into the rebates....this took flippin' ages...seriously, it was fiddly and delicate and almost drove me insane!
lines.text_raw: I then shaped the mahogany by hand to fit perfectly into the rebates....this took flippin' ages...seriously, it was fiddly and delicate and almost drove me insane!

lines.text: Everything got glued/clamped/sanded flush.
lines.text_raw: Everything got glued/clamped/sanded flush.

lines.text: I'm really glad I took my time over this...came out really nice!
lines.text_raw: I'm really glad I took my time over this...came out really nice!

lines.text: For the red buttons I drilled the center points and defined the edges with an 87mm hole cutter in my drill.
lines.text_raw: For the red buttons I drilled the center points and defined the edges with an 87mm hole cutter in my drill.

lines.text: The rebate was made using a router and a little chiseling.
lines.text_raw: The rebate was made using a router and a little chiseling.

lines.text: Then I made some circles from mahogany by hand and they got glued/clamped/sanded flush.
lines.text_raw: Then I made some circles from mahogany by hand and they got glued/clamped/sanded flush.

lines.text: The oak Start/Select button got done in a similar manner (sorry, not pictured).
lines.text_raw: The oak Start/Select button got done in a similar manner (sorry, not pictured).

lines.text: It all got a thorough sanding by hand down to 240grit;
lines.text_raw: It all got a thorough sanding by hand down to 240grit;

lines.text: Then some sanding sealant;
lines.text_raw: Then some sanding sealant;

lines.text: Then some clear wax.
lines.text_raw: Then some clear wax.

lines.text: Then I planed down the last of my maple for the edging, cut it to size, and mitred the corners.
lines.text_raw: Then I planed down the last of my maple for the edging, cut it to size, and mitred the corners.

lines.text: They were made to stick above the surface by 4mm so the glass should slip nicely into place.
lines.text_raw: They were made to stick above the surface by 4mm so the glass should slip nicely into place.

lines.text: They got biscuited and glued in place, with a bit of oak veneer in the corners 'cos I cut them too short....looks good though, let's just say I did on purpose, eh?
lines.text_raw: They got biscuited and glued in place, with a bit of oak veneer in the corners 'cos I cut them too short....looks good though, let's just say I did on purpose, eh?

lines.text: A bit more sanding and waxing and that's the tabletop done!
lines.text_raw: A bit more sanding and waxing and that's the tabletop done!

lines.text: For the legs of the table, I cut the oak roughly to size and planed/thicknessed it nice & square.
lines.text_raw: For the legs of the table, I cut the oak roughly to size and planed/thicknessed it nice & square.

lines.text: Then marked out the ends, and cut the mortices for rails...using a morticer. I then cut them to length.
lines.text_raw: Then marked out the ends, and cut the mortices for rails...using a morticer. I then cut them to length.

lines.text: I decided to put tapers on the legs, so made a jig for my table saw. (Always use the guards and suchlike on your tools, people! *guilty look*)
lines.text_raw: I decided to put tapers on the legs, so made a jig for my table saw. (Always use the guards and suchlike on your tools, people! *guilty look*)

lines.text: The tapers looked great...but left me with some scorch marks that took ages to sand out.
lines.text_raw: The tapers looked great...but left me with some scorch marks that took ages to sand out.

lines.text: I planed/thicknessed the oak for the rails, then cut to length, then cut tenons.
lines.text_raw: I planed/thicknessed the oak for the rails, then cut to length, then cut tenons.

lines.text: For the rail on the front I marked out where I wanted the drawers and drilled all the way through with a Forstner bit.
lines.text_raw: For the rail on the front I marked out where I wanted the drawers and drilled all the way through with a Forstner bit.

lines.text: I then cut between the holes with a jigsaw to take out the bulk.
lines.text_raw: I then cut between the holes with a jigsaw to take out the bulk.

lines.text: The edges were formed by tracing along a straight edge with a flush bit in the ol' router...then I spent too *!*! long sanding off the burn marks that left me!
lines.text_raw: The edges were formed by tracing along a straight edge with a flush bit in the ol' router...then I spent too *!*! long sanding off the burn marks that left me!

lines.text: I had some pine for the drawers kicking about so I cut the back and sides, then cut channels for the drawer runner and base (6mm ply).
lines.text_raw: I had some pine for the drawers kicking about so I cut the back and sides, then cut channels for the drawer runner and base (6mm ply).

lines.text: I put a strip of ply across the front of the drawer to make things a bit easier later, and it all got glued together & clamped.
lines.text_raw: I put a strip of ply across the front of the drawer to make things a bit easier later, and it all got glued together & clamped.

lines.text: I then made the runners for the drawer from some more softwood I had in the shed...I've always struggled with drawers in the past so totally over-engineered 'em to give as little play as possible, but without being too tight.
lines.text_raw: I then made the runners for the drawer from some more softwood I had in the shed...I've always struggled with drawers in the past so totally over-engineered 'em to give as little play as possible, but without being too tight.

lines.text: Then I made the drawer fronts so there would be about 1mm gap around them in the face rail.
lines.text_raw: Then I made the drawer fronts so there would be about 1mm gap around them in the face rail.

lines.text: The base got glued together, then the drawer rails glued in place.
lines.text_raw: The base got glued together, then the drawer rails glued in place.

lines.text: I then sanded it down to 240grit, gave it a good coat of sanding sealant, sanded it down to 400grit, and waxed.
lines.text_raw: I then sanded it down to 240grit, gave it a good coat of sanding sealant, sanded it down to 400grit, and waxed.

lines.text: I glued the drawer fronts in place with the drawer closed so I knew they'd fit just right.
lines.text_raw: I glued the drawer fronts in place with the drawer closed so I knew they'd fit just right.

lines.text: Last of all I attached a "push to open" fixing to the rear of the drawer - you push it in a mm or so and it pops open by itself, meaning there's no need for handles on the front.
lines.text_raw: Last of all I attached a "push to open" fixing to the rear of the drawer - you push it in a mm or so and it pops open by itself, meaning there's no need for handles on the front.

lines.text: And there we go!
lines.text_raw: And there we go!

lines.text: Right then...anyone want to commission me to make one for you?!
lines.text_raw: Right then...anyone want to commission me to make one for you?!
